creator: oldanvilyoungsmith
title: Drawing a multiview print (basic drafting)
description: This project explains the fundamentals of drawing a multiview print to clearly communicate designs, especially for hobbyists and makers who need to share their ideas effectively.
steps: Understand the six standard views: Top, bottom, front, back, right side, and left side. Choose the views that show the most necessary details.

Learn the different types of lines: Object lines (thick, solid lines for visible edges), Hidden lines (dashed lines for hidden edges), Center lines (alternating long and short dashes for centers), and Construction lines (light lines used for assistance and erased later).
Gather your drawing tools: a thin lead mechanical pencil, an eraser, a metal ruler with clear markings, a compass, and engineer’s paper.
Start with an existing part. Decide which side will be the front view based on which shows the most profile and detail.
Draw the front view first, as it is typically the most detailed and difficult.
Draw the next view (e.g., right side). Keep the views in line with one another and equal distances apart.
Use construction lines to draw the right side view. Erase them lightly later.
Draw the top view, using light construction lines from the front view to designate their position. Erase the construction lines after.
Add dimensions, ensuring to stand the dimension leader lines off of the part slightly.
Use the miter angle (a 45-degree line) to correspond lines between the top and side views, ensuring they align correctly.
